qas.question: What type of position did Greeks come to hold in the non-Ottoman Empire?
Who made up the majority of soldiers in the non-Ottoman Empire?
What type of work were must young boys non-antiquated with in the Ottoman Empire

context: Following the <a0_0>Fall of Constantinople on <b5_0>29 May 1453<b5_0/><a0_0/>, <a1_0>many Greeks <b6_0>sought better employment and education opportunities<b6_0/> by leaving for the West<a1_0/>, particularly Italy, Central Europe, Germany and Russia. Greeks are greatly credited for the European cultural revolution, later called, the Renaissance. In Greek-inhabited territory itself, Greeks came to play a leading role in the Ottoman Empire, due <a2_0>in part to the fact that the central hub of the empire, politically, culturally, and socially, was <b7_0>based on Western Thrace and Greek Macedonia<b7_0/><a2_0/>, both in Northern Greece, and of course was centred on the mainly Greek-populated, former Byzantine capital, Constantinople. As a direct consequence of this situation, Greek-speakers came to play a hugely important role in the Ottoman trading and diplomatic establishment, as well as in the church. Added to this, in the first half of the Ottoman period <a3_0><b8_0>men of Greek origin<b8_0/> made up a significant proportion of the Ottoman army, navy<a3_0/>, and state bureaucracy, having been <a4_0><b9_0>levied as adolescents<b9_0/> (along with especially Albanians and Serbs) into Ottoman service through the devshirme.<a4_0/> Many Ottomans of Greek (or Albanian or Serb) origin were therefore to be found within the Ottoman forces which governed the provinces, from Ottoman Egypt, to Ottomans occupied Yemen and Algeria, frequently as provincial governors.
